doc.str:
In response to the growing need to understand the response of plant and animal species to environmental variation and climate change and to develop a widespread baseline against which future phenological change may be measured, a consortium of scientists and agencies organized the USA-NPN, with a mandate to collect and share phenology data. More information on the USA-NPN can be found at http://www.usanpn.org/about.
As of January 1, 2013, the dataset contains phenology data on 591 species of plants and animals, with 7,512 locations registered across the United States. Protocols used are documented in Denny et. al., Submitted (contact nco@usanpn.org for more information). Data were collected using the phenophase status approach (Thomas et. al., 2010; Denny et. al. Submitted). Latitude and longitude given in WGS84 Datum. This is a suite of yearly data sets (Plants beginning in 2009, Animals beginning in 2010) each provided with and without full phenophase definitions.
Supplemental Information: Denny, E.G., K.L. Gerst, A.J. Miller-Rushing, G.L. Tierney, T.M. Crimmins, C.A.F. Enquist, P. Guertin, A.H. Rosemartin, M.D. Schwartz, K.A. Thomas and J.F. Weltzin. Submitted. Standardized phenology monitoring methods to track plant and animal activity for science and resource management applications.
Thomas, K.A., E.G. Denny, A.J. Miller-Rushing, T.M. Crimmins, and J.F. Weltzin. 2010. The National Phenology Monitoring System v0.1. USA-NPN Technical Series 2010-001. www.usanpn.org.
USA National Phenology Network (USA-NPN) Plant and Animal Phenology Data for the United States, 2012

arr.name: attributeDescription
arr.str: Group to which the plant or animal belongs.

The Species and Protocols Group (S&P) applied a combination of desired criteria and applications to a comprehensive plant database (http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/) and has developed a list of about 150 species, which will be vetted by participating networks and programs. The primary goal of this selection is to establish a baseline of phenological patterns for plants and animals across the nation, help monitor and detect phenological responses to climate change, immediately demonstrate the national scope of network, and engage the largest possible number of participants within a backbone network.
The genus to which the species belongs.
Website on usanpn.org/nn that contains the protocol for the species.
The unique identifier for each record in this data set, and the primary key in the observation table of the National Phenology Database.
The date the observation was made.
The time the observation was made.
The day of the year the observation was made.
The unique identifier for the site at which the observation was recorded.
The latitude of the observation location (site).
The longitude of the observation location (site).
The yes, no, or uncertain value for a phenophase.
The elevation, in meteres, of the observation location (from USGS web service, or free-form entered by the user).
The United State postal code, or Canadian province code, in which the observation was made.
The genus name of the organism on which the observation was made.
The species name of the organism on which the observation was made.
The common name of the species observed.
The unique identifier for tha plant or animal species for which the observation is about. For animals, the number definies the species; for plants, the number defines the individual plant.
Unique identifier for the phenophase name
The category description for the Intensity_Question.
The question asked of the observer about the intensity or abundance of the phenophase observed.
Bin of values reported to answer the Intensity_Question for plant species.
Number of individual animals observed in the phenophase asked in the Intensity_Question. A value of-1 means either no value is reported, or that species/phenophase doesn't support raw abundance.
Group names to which the species being observed belongs.
The unique identifier for the phenophase.

arr.name: attribute
arr.str: Group Group to which the plant or animal belongs.

Focal Species The Species and Protocols Group (S&P) applied a combination of desired criteria and applications to a comprehensive plant database (http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/) and has developed a list of about 150 species, which will be vetted by participating networks and programs. The primary goal of this selection is to establish a baseline of phenological patterns for plants and animals across the nation, help monitor and detect phenological responses to climate change, immediately demonstrate the national scope of network, and engage the largest possible number of participants within a backbone network.
Genus The genus to which the species belongs.
Common_Name Common name of the species.
URL Website on usanpn.org/nn that contains the protocol for the species.
Observation_ID The unique identifier for each record in this data set, and the primary key in the observation table of the National Phenology Database.
Observation_Date The date the observation was made.
Observation_Time The time the observation was made.
Day_of_Year The day of the year the observation was made. nominalDay
Site_ID The unique identifier for the site at which the observation was recorded.
Latitude The latitude of the observation location (site). degree
Longitude The longitude of the observation location (site). degree
Phenophase_Status The yes, no, or uncertain value for a phenophase.
Elevation The elevation, in meteres, of the observation location (from USGS web service, or free-form entered by the user). meter
State The United State postal code, or Canadian province code, in which the observation was made.
Genus The genus name of the organism on which the observation was made.
Species The species name of the organism on which the observation was made.
Common_Name The common name of the species observed.

Individual_ID The unique identifier for tha plant or animal species for which the observation is about. For animals, the number definies the species; for plants, the number defines the individual plant.
Phenophase_ID Unique identifier for the phenophase name
Phenophase_Name The title for each phenophase
Intensity_Category_ID The category description for the Intensity_Question.
Intensity_Question The question asked of the observer about the intensity or abundance of the phenophase observed.
Intensity_Value Bin of values reported to answer the Intensity_Question for plant species.

Raw_Abundance_Value Number of individual animals observed in the phenophase asked in the Intensity_Question. A value of-1 means either no value is reported, or that species/phenophase doesn't support raw abundance. dimensionless
Species_Types Group names to which the species being observed belongs.
Phenophase_ID The unique identifier for the phenophase.
Phenophase_Name The title of the phenophase.
Description The description of the phenophase
